name: Through the Woods
description: Through the Woods is a third-person Norse horror adventure set in a forest on the western shores of Norway that tells the story of a mother and her missing son.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 / 8 / 8.1 / 10 Processor: Dual-Core 2.8 GHz Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce GTX 760 / 960 or equivalent with 2 GB VRAM DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 10 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX® 11 compatible
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 / 8 / 8.1 / 10 Processor: Intel Core i5 or equivalent CPU rated at 3,5 GHz Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce GTX 980 or equivalent DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 10 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX® 11 compatible

reviews.review_text: I don't normally write game reviews, as most of the games I've purchased have either been somewhat satisfactory or worth the price, but let me just say that the praise this game is receiving is totally off. I tried playing this with my girlfriend, and we really tried giving it a chance, but between the clunky controls, chuggy framerate (my machine runs DOOM, MGS 5, Vive games, etc, on highest settings), bad performances, and generally boring gameplay, I can't say I would ever recommend it. If you want a scary 3rd person game, there are plenty of options better than this. In a nutshell, this is overpriced amateur hour.  The easy-to-read version of my review for Zeux:  bad controls, bad framerate, bad acting, boring, overpriced.

I don't like that many horror games, especially if they have jump scares. I've played 45 minutes of this game so far, and it's been very interesting, and not a single jump scare. It's definitely an eerie game.
If you are a fan of Norse Mythology, or the show VIkings, this is the horror game for you! One of the game's best qualities is its ability to make yourself get creeped out.

While interesting, this is yet another linear walking (running) sim where you find notes and hear audio that tell a story. You will come across some interesting monsters/creatures, but you can't fight back. You can only use a flashlight (with thankfully no battery life to deal with) even thought the character comes across many swords and other weapons.   I'm a bit burned out in this type of game after playing Gone Home, Dear Ester, Vanishing of Ethan Carter, Kholot, etc and was expecting a bit more. I was sold on the original trailer and avoided reviews as to not spoil the game for myself.  With that said, you may like It and should give it a try at least.
The atmosphere, design and monsters are great. The voice acting and gameplay are not. Game runs poorly, always stuttering. It got boring kind of quickly.
Looks like it would be good. But the performance and rendering issues at modern high end resoltuiotn made me refund the game. If you are gong to charge this much, get the tech part right atleast.
